France has stepped up its no-deal preparations.ndash Asking for an extension of Article : Mrs May has previously insisted almost to the point of foot-stamping that Britain will leave the EU on March , and a U-turn here would enrage already puce Brexiteers.But writing in the Observer, Unison general secretary Dave Prentis said: ldquoThe PM has pushed us dangerously close to the exit door with perilously little left on the clock.ldquoSo itrsquos vital that immediate steps be taken to extend article .ldquoNot to stop Brexit, but to ensure that therersquos time to force a change of government, or find a solution parliament can back.ndash Halting Article : A court case last year ruled that, while all  other EU states have to agree to extend the Article  process of leaving, the UK can unilaterally reverse it. Neither the Tories nor Labour support a halt but Philip Hammond reportedly told business leaders in a conference call on Wednesday that a bill being rustled up by backbenchers would have this as its aim.ndash A second referendum: Labour members at conference left the door open to supporting a new vote on leavingthe party could not trigger a general election. Mr Corbyn was applauded by Labour activists when he pointed this out in a speech on Thursday. But he also indicated he would rather leave with a Labour-flavoured Withdrawal Agreement.Former attorney general Dominic Grieve wrote in the Sunday Times: ldquoI have made no secret of my support for the Peoplersquos Vote campaign but it is important to recognise that this idea may well gain support only at the end of a process when every possible Brexit option has been explored.ldquoI do not doubt that legislating for a new referendum is a dficult decision and the last resort for many MPs.ldquoWe must, however, pursue this debate with courtesy, listening to those of other views and finding areas of common interest, but keeping our own preference in mind. I am convinced on grounds both of common sense and the national interest that a new public vote will be helpful to resolving this crisis.ndash No-deal Brexit: If Theresa May loses and Parliament cannot come together behind an alternative, the UK will leave the European Union on March  without a deal. This is something to either be afraid of, or not afraid of, depending on your view of Brexit.

title: jobs-boost-for-larkhall-as-council-gives-green-light-for-new-lidl-store
story: The new supermarket will be built on the townrsquos Carlisle Road.The supermarket first revealed in January  that it wanted to open a new store at the site of the closed Sefton Park Care Home as part of its ongoing expansion in the UK.Construction is estimated to start on site in the spring with a view to open the store in .The multi million-pound investment will see Lidl build a sustainable store with msup sales area with plans to create up to  new jobs.The supermarket will feature facilities including an instore bakery, customer toilets and ldquoample parking for both cars and bicycles.Lidl UKrsquos regional head of property, Gordon Rafferty, said: ldquoWe could not be more delighted to have received planning permission, and look forward to getting started on construction.ldquoIrsquod like to take this opportunity to thank the local community for their continued support, and very much look forward to opening our doors and offering our fresh, quality, great value products in the not too distant future.Lidl has experienced continued growth in Scotland over the years as more and more cost-conscious consumers flock to budget supermarkets.The refurbishment of the Larkhall store will add to Lidlrsquos existing store portfolio In the UK of , and will form part of the companyrsquos growth plans, which will see it open to  new stores a year across the UK.

title: ronnie-spector-on-john-lennon-phil-spector-and-loving-life-at-75
story: Then the song starts. Hal Blainrsquos sticks beat out the rhythm. So familiar, still so fresh.Boom hellip Boom, boom.Boom hellip Boom, boom.The band joins in and then the voice jumps up, cuts through. ldquoThe night we met I knew I needed you so hellipThat voice, so tough, so tender.ldquoSo, wont you, please, be my, be my baby Be my little baby, my one and only baby hellipThis is pop. Then and now and foreverRonnie Spector is in bed when I call. Shersquos not long back from doing a show and right now shersquos having a coffee at home in Connecticut. ldquoIrsquoll go back to sleep after I talk to you, Teddy.It sounds a spartan room. Therersquos a plant she loves and a picture of a Chinese woman in a red outfit. ldquoAnd my TV of course.Therersquos also a calendar on the wall. One that marks all the gigs shersquos played and all the gigs shersquos due to play. Therersquos an X on there that means Glasgow. In a couple of weeks, she will leave her home to travel here to play at Celtic Connections where she will sing the old songs and tell us about the people she knew. Boom hellip boom, boom. Itrsquos why wersquore talking.But, really, wersquore talking because shersquos Ronnie Spector. The voice of The Ronettes. The woman who gave voice to some of Phil Spectorrsquos finest early recordings. The woman who would then marry her producer and go through all kinds of hell until she freed herself and started again.The woman beloved by Springsteen and John Lennon and Martin Scorsese , the woman who was embraced by the American punk fraternity and then namechecked by Madonna. Ronnie Spector. Poprsquos original bad girl . ldquoWe werenrsquot afraid to look hot, she once said of the Ronettes in their s heyday. ldquoThat was our gimmick.Ronnie Spector, now , in her bed drinking coffee and talking to a journalist in Glasgow about the past and the present and finding nothing but good things to say about both.ldquoI was in Glasgow and Scotland a few times in the sixties. I remember the accent was harder than the London accent. I remember the pipers and how they would wear skirts and all that. I remember that well.Read More: Celtic Connections: The Top Ten Must See ShowsIn our time together, she tells me the stories that she tells every journalist about Lennon ndash that time in New York in the s when he saw her in the street and shouted ldquoHey Ronnie Ronette Dick Clarkrsquos Caravan of Stars about that time in the studio when she started singing Be My Baby for the first time and all the musicians just stopped.ldquoIt was like we were in the Twilight Zone. The musicians in the place were going crazy. You remember that feeling how they looked at you and said, lsquoWow, thatrsquos a dferent voice.Theyrsquore good stories, ones we want to hear. But shersquod rather not talk about her ex-husband , thank you. It was  years ago, and shersquos said enough about that. Therersquos a bookyou really want to know, she reminds me.What Irsquom interested in is the before and after of the story. The place where she comes from and the place she is in now, the place she had to fight to get to.The before is easy. Spanish Harlem, Upper Manhattan, at the turn of the s. She makes it sound like paradise.ldquoWhen I was growing up, Teddy, we had everybody in our neighbourhood, so I didnrsquot think about race or colour or anything like that.Spector comes from a mixed-race family. Her dad was Irish, her mum was ldquoblack and Cherokee. Her skin was lighter as a result, but race or colour didnrsquot figure much, she says.ldquoI thought everybody had a neighbourhood like mine, with Jewish delis and Chinese restaurants and black barbecue places. I grew up in a wonderful time. There were no gangs or dope. It was just a wonderful regular childhood. It wasnrsquot crazy.In my mind, I tell her, back then there were doo wop groups singing on every corner in Spanish Harlem. ldquoWe didnrsquot see much of the doo wops on the street, she admits. ldquoWe werenrsquot allowed to go out that much. But I love that because we had a huge family and we were protected. Thatrsquos why a lot of groups got messed up because they didnrsquot have anybody to trust. My mother travelled everywhere with us England, Scotland, America, everywhere, so it was like coming home from school. We never got into drugs and alcohol and all that stuff because your mother was there.I imagine it must have been an eye-opener when she did then go on tour and find that America wasnrsquot really like Spanish Harlem. But Spector says not. ldquoYou didnrsquot think of race, she says.That said, she does recall being on tour as part of Dick Clarkrsquos Caravan of Stars, a package put together by the American radio and TV presenter, and stopping who knows where, but definitely not Spanish Harlem, for food.One black doo wop group wouldnrsquot get off the bus, she remembers. ldquoThey said, lsquoRonnie, would you bring us back a hamburger rsquo I thought it was strange, but at  you didnrsquot pay that any attention. I didnrsquot know what I know now that they were actually afraid to get off the bus.Spector always sang. She remembers at five getting up on the coffee table at home and singing silly songs to a family audience. ldquoMy family would applaud and that stuck in my mind forever.When she was eight Spector used to go her grandmotherrsquos after school with her cousins and shersquod stand in the lobby and sing. ldquoIt was the echo in that hallway that made me feel like, I can really sing. Irsquom like eight or nine years old and Irsquom singing Frankie Lymon songs and all my cousins are backing me up with all the doo wop stuff and thatrsquos my first memory of saying lsquoI can sing.rsquoIn  Frankie Lymon ndash a Harlem boy, a boy destined for self-destruction, a boy who would OD on heroin at the age of  ndash released an album entitled At the London Palladium. She loved it, loved Frankiersquos voice. A few years later The Ronettes would be at the Palladium themselves.When Spector was  years old The Ronettes played the Apollo amateur night. ldquoMy mother would say to me, lsquoIf they like you yoursquove got it made,they donrsquot, finish your schoolwork.rsquoldquoThey loved me, so I knew that I would be a somebody in the business. I didnrsquot know how or when or who.The when was , the who Phil Spector, the how was singing Be My Baby.Other hits would follow. Baby I Love You, Walking in the Rain, most notably. The sixties had started, pop music in all its immediacy and innocence was in full bloom and The Ronettes were part of that. ldquoWe looked dferent from everybody . We had our own hair when most groups wore wigs.Success meant access. Spector met the Beatles, toured with the Stones. These days she lives just  minutes away from Keith Richards. She met him a month ago when she was going into her dentist and he was coming out.ldquoHis daughter was with him. Hersquos a changed man from that seventies era and whatever they were going through. Hersquos a great dad.Read More: Jenna Reid on launching album Working Hands at Celtic ConnectionsRonnie, I say, who was your favourite Beatle  ldquoJohn. As simple as that. He was so nice, and his mind was really intact. He knew what he wanted to do, knew what he wanted to write. We were friends. He took me to Carnaby Street and showed me where to get the T-shirts and the boots. Irsquod come back to America looking all English.ldquoHe was really my favourite one. We dated a couple of times. He took me to a couple of clubs and I remember him leaning over to me and saying, lsquoRonnie, sing a little bit of Be My Baby in my ear.rsquo And I sang, lsquoThe night we met I needed you so helliprsquo I looked over and he had passed out.Good memories. There are bad memories too. The fairy-tale le she was leading took a grim turn when she married Phil Spector. She met the producer, the ldquofirst tycoon of teenwhen she was . He made her a star and then he took it all away from her.The day after their wedding, she wrote in her  memoir Be My Baby: How I Survived Mascara, Miniskirts and Madness, she woke up to see men erecting barbed wire and gates around the Spector mansion in Beverley Hills.In the years that followed she found herself trapped at home by a controlling, abusive, paranoid man. He robbed her of performing, robbed her of her voice .The story has the odd black comic edge. When she did get permission to leave the house she had to drive in a car with a blow-up Phil Spector doll in the back. But her account of those years when published is mostly pure horror show. In the end she had to sneak out of the house and flee with the help of her mother.If anything, her memoir might have downplayed things. In  in an ultimately unsuccessful bid for unpaid royalties, Spector would claim in court that her husband pulled a gun on her during their marriage. In  Spector was found guilty of the murder of Lana Clarkson in Spectorrsquos home.Perhaps, given everything, we shouldnrsquot be surprised that she doesnrsquot want to talk about any of this now.ldquoEverybody knows that story. It wasnrsquot a relationship. I wrote a book about it. Itrsquos been well over  years since I left. I prefer the music we made together to speak rather than dwell on the negative, she says when I tentatively broach the subject.ldquoAs a matter of fact, that made me more positive today. All the hell I went through made me the woman I am today. I dusted myself off and went on with it. When I was there I wasnrsquot singing and that was my passion and without my singing it wasnrsquot even a world I was living in. It was hell.ldquoThatrsquos why I love the #MeToo movement now. I wish they had it in the sixties. Because it was a manrsquos world back then. Men were producers. Men were writers. We were like employees rather than artists.ldquoSo now my le is great. I have no regrets about het past because it made me the woman I am today. Period, Teddy.Indeed. So, letrsquos celebrate that. Because this is the story of a woman who is a survivor, a woman who put the past behind her, who married againand who still gets up on stage at the age of  and sings those old songs and takes as much pleasure from doing so as she did  years ago. More maybe.ldquoI feel grown up when Irsquom singing now. I donrsquot feel like a little girl, she says.ldquoIrsquoll tell you something Teddy,I thought something years ago that the crowd would be going crazy over me more now than they did then I would think you were crazy Ronnie, but they really are.ldquoI get crowds who are young, middle and old. Itrsquos so amazing to me to look out in the audience and see all these young girls with the beehive hairstyle and the eyeliner just like me. Itrsquos amazing.Itrsquos an idea she s to again and again. ldquoIrsquove never stopped loving it. Itrsquos my passion. Itrsquos what I do. Itrsquos what I wake up in the morning for.Boom hellip boom, boom.Ronnie Spector and the Ronettes play the Old Fruitmarket, Glasgow on Wednesday as part of Celtic Connections.RONNIE SPECTOR ON THE MUSIC INDUSTRY TODAYldquoItrsquos amazing now women are writing for themselves. Now itrsquos Taylor Swt, people like that, who write for themselves now. Back then, men made all the money.ldquoYou couldnrsquot even write for yourself andyou did you didnrsquot get any credit back then. If you put certain words in a song you didnrsquot get any credit. So, now women are really making their own money and not depending on the producers or the record companies to make them millions. And that to me is so great, I canrsquot tell you.

title: trans-rights-backlash-the-scottish-canadian-connection
story: To listen to those leading the chants ndash including ldquoNo TERFs, not KKK, no fascists here today! ndash youd be forgiven for thinking headline speaker Meghan Murphy was some kind of racist and colonialist, prone to inciting violent acts against minorities. What would not be immediately clear is that Murphys crime, in the eyes of those who would silence her, is stating that men cannot become women.In fact her opponents would argue this is not just a crime in their eyes, but also according to the laws of the land. The reach of these laws ndash some federal, others provincial ndash is currently being tested, including in high-profile legal actions that are making headlines around the world.So why is a discussion on Gender Identity Ideology and Womens Rights so controversial, and what can Scotland learn from Canada about how to legislate around the contentious area of transgender rights  Equally, what might Canada be able to learn from us Our two nations have a few things in common. Each has a neighbour to the south with a population about ten times higher, each is led by a self-declared feminist, and each governing party prides itself on being progressive, especially in comparison to those southern neighbours. The leaders of both countries are, accordingly, loudly and proudly committed to promoting LGBT rights.Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was already a regular at Pride marches before his election in , while last year Nicola Sturgeon led Glasgow Pride during Donald Trumps visit to Scotland, shortly before the Scottish Government committed to including LGBT issues across the school curriculum. Back in November , weeks after Sturgeon apologised at Holyrood to gay men convicted of sexual offences that are no longer illegal, Trudeau issued a formal apology in the Ottawa legislature for the past oppression of the LGBTQ communities.Incidentally, the ldquo stands for two-spirited, a term that refers exclusively to indigenous people with distinct spiritual and ceremonial roles in their communities.The worldwide gender identity debate is, at heart, a debate about the meaning of words. In particular, the words ldquowoman, ldquoman and "lesbian". It is a debate about whether iniduals, groups, political parties or governments have the right to redefine those words, then compel others to accept the new meanings.The meaning of "woman" matters because this has implications for women-only spaces such as toilets, changing rooms and refuges. It matters because of the impact on all-women shortlists and womens sports. It matters because women around the world suffer discrimination as a consequence of being born female.Because the meaning of words directly affects how people ndash including the small minority who are transgender ndash navigate their day-to-day lives, this is a heated debate. And while many women politely nod along with mantras like "transwomen are women", either believing themselves to be progressive or fearful of the consequences of doing otherwise, many feminists are refusing to comply.It is a sufficiently heated debate that when Murphy and her fellow lists started to address an audience of around  women late on a Thursday night last week, there were more than two dozen security guards in the room and police officers too.Those who challenge the idea that men can become womenhave been called many things ndash ldquoTERFs , transphobes, bigots and even Nazis but in Canada ldquocoloniser is added to the mix, with the implication that such iniduals are also anti-indigenous people, anti-immigrant and pro-deportations. This goes down badly with those among their opponents who are indeed radical feminists, aligned to the left.Murphy grew up in a left-wing household, with a father who campaigned for Canadas New Democratic Party. But in recent years, since ldquocoming out as critical of gender identity ideology, she has found herself courted by those on the right, even those who strongly disagree with her positions on other issues such as abortion. When she was last year handed a permanent ban from social media site Twitter for questioning gender identity ideology ndash and then questioning Twitter for punishing her for doing so ndash she received a flood of supportive messages from right-wingers including Ben Shapiro, the influential US commentator.ldquoOf course Im aware that some of those outlets are using me for their own means, which is like, look at what the left is doing, its eating itself, but I dont really care, because theyre right, she says with a wry laugh.She believes politicians on the left who have backed a steady stream of policy changes informed by gender identity ideology ndash relating to everything from signage and the census to prisons and hate speech ndash are poorly informed. ldquoI think the politicians are advised to take a certain line and dont at all understand the implications of the arguments, and dont really think about it very much ... and eventhey did Im sure they would be too scared to say anything.Among those who have taken that line is Vancouvers newly elected mayor, Kennedy Stewart, who said of Murphys event: ldquoI find it despicable ... its not something I support at all. Murphy attempted to contact Stewart to find out what, exactly, he found despicable , but she received no response. Its clear, however, that Vancouver is very keen to promote itself as an LGBT-friendly city. Signs on lampposts ldquocelebrate queer Vancouver, stickers on doors announce ldquosafe places and rainbow and trans flags adorn public buildings.Unlike in Scotland, where the Scottish Trans Alliance has received government funding since , in Canada there is no national organisation pushing for changes to transgender rights. There are also no national womens rights campaign groups comparable to the UK-wide Fair Play for Women, Womens Place UKor For Women Scotland, arguing for the importance of protections based on biological sex. As a result there has been very little public debate about the implications of signicant changes ndash that is, except for the very public opposition of psychology professor Jordan Peterson to the inclusion of gender identity as a prohibited ground of discrimination.The question of gender identity has been in the news on this side of the Atlantic for months due to proposed changes to the Gender Recognition Act ndash a piece of legislation that was passed following a European Court of Human Rights case in . The introduction of the GRA meant that people who identied as the opposite sex could change their legal sex by amending their birth certicates. At that time it was already possible to change the sex recorded on documents such as driving licences and passports, but transwoman Christine Goodwin argued that because she had been refused a new National Insurance number that reflected her new identity, an employer had gained knowledge of her past living as a man and discriminated against her on this basis. The court ruled that preventing trans people from changing their legal sex contravened the European Convention on Human Rights.As the law stands, those applying to change their birth certicates must satisfy a  of medical and legal professionals that they have experienced gender dysphoria, defined by the NHS as ldquoa condition where a person experiences discomfort or distress because theres a mismatch between their biological sex and gender identity have lived in their acquired gender for two years and intended to live in that gender for le. Concepts such as ldquoliving in a gender were not defined in the legislation, with their interpretation left to those appointed to Gender Recognition Panels. Transgender activists now argue that restrictive, stereotypical notions of gender are used to assess whether an applicant is indeed ldquoliving in a given gender, and that the UKs approach wrongly characterises transgender identities as evidence of psychological problems. These are among the reasons why they argue that the UKshould adopt a system of gender self-ID, scrapping Gender Recognition Panels and instead requiring applicants to make a statutory declaration about their identity.The debate about Scotlands census, changes to which are being considered by the Culture, Tourism, Europe and External Affairs Committee, has become a proxy debate about self-ID, highlighting the fact that the current census format conflates sex and gender . The Scottish Government consulted on reforms to the Gender Recognition Act last year, and has pledged to bring forward legislation in this area soon.Official attitudes in Scotland have changed over time, due in large part to the efforts over the past decade of James Morton of the Scottish Trans Alliance. Writing about the challenges of securing and retaining funding for a trans-specic equality project, Morton has noted that the SNP, which inherited his pilot project from the previous coalition government in , ldquowere keen for the rest of Europe to recognise Scotland as a progressive, innovative country. He also explains the strategic thinking behind working with the Scottish Prison Service to introduce a gender identity policy ndashprisons could be persuaded to adopt a policy based on self-declaration in ldquovery challenging circumstances, other public services would likely follow.Those challenging circumstances have been in the spotlight since it emerged that Karen White, a male rapist who identies as a woman but is still legally male, had sexually assaulted female inmates after being remanded in a womens prison in England. White was described as an ldquoalleged transgender female by a prosecutor who suggested there was little evidence of any meaningful transition, but last week it was reported that the serial sex offender ndash who is serving a le sentence ndash is seeking cash from friends to fund gender reassignment surgery, in the belief this will guarantee a transfer back to the female estate.Trans activists argue that such cases are exceptions and that those who oppose prison policies based on self-ID are unfairly seeking to portray all transgender people as sexual predators. Womens rights groups argue that vulnerable women in prison, many of whom have experienced physical and sexual violence, have the right to be housed separately from males.They also argue that spaces such as womens refuges should be permitted to refuse males, and in Canada this is a contentious subject. Back in , a transwoman named Kimberly Nixon sought to volunteer as a counsellor for Vancouver Rape Relief, and when she was rejected on the grounds that she had not been born female she took the charity to the British Columbia Human Rights Tribunal. She won the case, and was awarded , for injury to her self-respect and dignity, but the charity sought a judicial review and the case ended up in the Supreme Court, which ruled against Nixon and asserted that the charity was entitled to apply its women-only policy.Lee Lakeman, a pioneering feminist and fierce advocate for abused women, worked at Vancouver Rape Relief for  years. She joined the  for Murphys event in the city and delivered a passionate defence of female-only spaces, warning: ldquoTo those who imagine you can bully us into submission: you are clearly unfamiliar with us.One might imagine that a transgender person taking a rape charity to court would have damaged the cause of transgender rights, but it appears only to have damaged the charity. When a business in the city recently displayed a poster advertising a Rape Relief fundraiser in its window, its owner received a barrage of abuse and negative Facebook reviews. It remains to be seen whether a male taking more than a dozen female beauticians to the British Columbia Human Rights Tribunal claiming discrimination on gender identity grounds ndash after they all refused to wax ldquoher male genitals ndash will be similarly supported by the transgender community and its allies.In the end Murphys event passed without disruption, perhaps unsurprisingly given the muscle on hand to enforce it. By the time the last stragglers left ndash in pairs for their safety, as instructed ndash they found that many of those who had been chanting out in the cold had since abandoned their placards and gone home. However, a local trans activist later argued that by allowing the event to be broadcast online, Vancouver Public Library knowingly took part in ldquopublishing to the internet an incitement to discriminate on the basis of gender identity or expression, an action prohibited by section seven of the Human Rights Code.As the Canadian left continues to eat itself, Scotland is having an in-depth discussion about what it means to be a woman or a man, in law and in our society. The wording of questions on the census might not seem like a vitally important matter, but the Canadian experience shows just how quickly small changes can have far-reaching effects.

title: sir-tom-hunter-hails-progress-made-with-west-lothian-new-town-plan-amid-brexit-uncertainty
story: Sir Tomrsquos West Coast Capital is set to make a multi-million pound investment in coming decades in the , home Winchburgh project in spite of the uncertainty about what Brexit will mean.However, hammering home his view that there should be a second referendum on Brexit, Sir Tom underlined his confidence the investment will pay off whatever storms may lie ahead.Read more: Sir Tom Hunter lamanets utter scandal of Brexit voteldquoPeople say are you investing at the right time  Irsquove no idea butyou sit on your hands and wait for politicians to sort things out yoursquoll never invest a penny, said Sir Tom.He complained that politicians had badly failed in their handling of Brexit. The public had not been given the facts required to make an informed decision and had even been told lies in advance of the referendum in .ldquoNow that we know what Brexit could look like we need to go back and say why are we leaving, noted Sir Tom, who reckons the case for a second peoplersquos referendum has become unanswerable.Read more: Sir Tom Hunter grows property profits as he ponders West Lothian questionRegarding Winchburgh, he added: ldquoAs long as we get the financial structure right itrsquos never going to come under pressure. If there are downturns we can weather those storms.West Coastrsquos confidence in the Winchburgh plan has increased after the company won backing for the project from one of the UKrsquos biggest insurers and struck key agreements with the Scottish Government and West Lothian Council to support work on the related infrastructure.As well as providing homes for thousands of people, the development will include four new schools, a motorway spur, a giant public park and a new railway station.ldquoThe fact that we are building a new town and the station will be  minutes from Edinburgh Haymarket, to be able to build something on that scale is something quite exciting, observed Sir Tom.After losing some of the fortune he made from the poundm sale of his Sports Division business when investments in house builders went badly during the financial crisis, Sir Tom has persevered with plans for Winchburgh in the face of big challenges.Read more: Ayrshire entrepreneur flags focus on unlisted investmentsHe bought into the project in  in the belief that Winchburghrsquos location meant it was ideally placed to benefit from long term developments in the economy in the area only to find some firms dropped out amid the downturn triggered by the credit crunch.West Coast spent years trying to secure the public support needed to develop the infrastructure required to make plans for the town viable.The company announced yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with Cala Homes to invest in the development and delivery of the overall masterplan for Winchburgh.Details of the agreement have not been disclosed but Sir Tom said it will entail multi-million investment. He noted that Cala was acquired last year by le and pensions giant Legal  General, which has made clear it is ready to invest in the housebuilding sector in the long term.ldquoTheresrsquos some heavy lting going on now, said Sir Tom. ldquoRather than put in debt we decided to look for a partner who shared our long-term view.Cala will build some homes at Winchburgh. It will work with West Coast to complete the developments required to ensure other housebuilders buy land on the site. Sir Tom noted a first phase development won support from five housebuilders, including Miller and Taylor Wimpey. These built and sold around  homes.West Lothian Council will build two secondary and two primary schools, which will ultimately be paid for by house builders via receipts from the roof tax.The Building Scotland Fund is lending pound.m to support infrastructure investment.

title: equal-pay-agreement-is-just-the-beginning-of-the-end-for-glasgow
story: Though both the council and the lawyers and trade unions representing the , affected women conceded that ldquovaluable progress had been made since the claimants staged a two-day strike in October, there were simply too many sticking points to overcome before a final settlement could be agreed.Given that the case had already rumbled on for over a decade and that those affected will continue to receive unfair salaries even when the settlement goes through, that is hardly surprising.But, with all sides keen to get the deal away, a breakthrough came two weeks ago when, as key negotiator Stefan Cross put it, everyone agreed to ldquodraw a line under the past and get to the future when we get to the future.As a result, the sides were able to stop quibbling about what might happen when the councilrsquos discredited pay scheme is replaced in the next two years and focus instead on ensuring the women are paid all the wages they should rightfully have received up to this point.And so - finally - a pound million package that will translate into average inidual pay-outs of pound, was agreed this week, allowing the SNP-led council to finally bring an end to a problem that the former Labour-run administration had not only created but perpetuated.No wonder council leader Susan Aitken, who said after the agreement was reached that her ldquocommitment to resolving this issue has never wavered and I have never needed to be convinced of the case for equality, felt able to gloat.ldquoAfter a decade of obstruction and inaction, in a relatively short space of time we have now reached agreement which delivers the pay justice these women long have fought for, she said.The agreement is hardly an end in itself, though. Ms Aitken still has to get sign off from a full council her party only has minority control of while the women - who are represented iously by Mr Crossrsquos firm Action  Equality Scotland and trade unions the GMB, Unison and Unite - will need to agree their inidual settlements.Given the time and effort that has gone into reaching the agreement, those matters are considered to be formalities, although there could be a small number of cases where further negotiation is required.The bigger issue from the councilrsquos point of view will be raising the necessary finance to ensure it can meet its stated aim of settling all , claims by December this year.It will be no small task. Though Ms Aitken made settling the dispute a priority when she took over from Labourrsquos Frank McAveety in , the previous administration had been so convinced that it could defeat the women through the courts that it made practically no financial provision for a potential settlement.With less than poundm in its contingency fund when Labour left office, the SNP-led council set aside poundm in the   financial year, all of which will now be put towards the settlement.It will also look to extend its existing debt facilities - which at the end of   stood poundm lower than a year previously at pound. billion - and mortgage some of the non-operational buildings held on its behalf by arms- organisation City Property.While raising half a billion pounds should not cause too much of a problem for a council as asset-rich as Glasgow, it is understood that all those financing deals are yet to be done meaning time, more than anything, is going to be of the essence.Then, of course, there will be the future to deal with.The starting point for this entire process was the pay structure put in place in  following an agreement between the Labour administration and the then male-dominated trade unions.Although it was supposed to eradicate an unfair system that had previously seen male workers earn bonuses their female counterparts were not entitled to, in truth all that pay scheme did was lock those bonuses in, perpetuating the inequality in the process.While the poundm settlement will compensate the women for that, the discredited pay system - and so the pay inequality - will remain in place for at least the next two years while work gets under way on devising a new scheme.It is going to be a complicated process, not just because there is an obvious need to get it right this time, but because it is going to require the value of , dferent jobs to be assessed, compared and signed off by both the council and the unions.When it is done, a further settlement will have to be negotiated to make amends for any pay inequalities during the period between this weekrsquos poundm settlement being paid out and the new pay grades taking effect .As Unison Scottish secretary Mike Kirby said when the settlement was agreed on Thursday: ldquoWhile we have made great progress, we still have a lot of work to do.With the council facing bringing thousands of female workersrsquo pay packets into line with those of just a few hundred male staff one thing is for sure: it promises to continue to be a costly business.

title: paul-hutcheon-delaying-brexit-is-vital-if-no-deal-departure-is-to-avoided
story: IT would not take a clairvoyant to predict that the UK is facing the most serious rupture since the second world war in fewer than  days.Here is how it might play out. By mid-March, Theresa May has successfully headed off a softer Brexit proposed by a coalition of MPs and defeated plans for second referendum by exploiting Labour isions.With the country hurtling towards a no-deal departure, the Prime Minister secures concessions from European partners and puts a revised deal in front of the Commons which wins over some Tory doubters.Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the SNP oppose the new draft, but May is confident support from the Democratic Unionist Party and Tory colleagues will suffice. On the day, a hard core of Brexiteers who still have misgivings derail the plan and defeat the Prime Minister. As a result of Westminster paralysis, the UK crashes out of the European Union without a deal on March th.The consequences for the UK economy and society are immediate. Excessive form-filling at ports in the south of England has led to queues of more than  miles in the UK and France. Farmers are panicking about the lack of seasonal harvest workers and warning about the impact of World Trade Organisation rules on exporting their products.Hotels, pubs and restaurants are also complaining about the effect of no deal on their ability to recruit staff and shoppers staring at empty shelves in supermarkets. Car manufacturers announce plans to relocate from the UK and the financial services sector loses vital passporting rights.But it is the strain on the NHS that is causing the most anger. The cost of medicines is to rise sharply and the Health Secretary has conceded that delays will affect the importation of le-saving drugs. All waiting times targets are suspended for five years and thousands of UK nationals in the EU are unsurethey can receive any care.A no-deal Brexit, and the chaos many predict will ensue, is a live prospect because of the terms laid out in the Lisbon Treaty on how to leave the European Union. Once a country invokes Article  ndash the beginning of the withdrawal process ndash the same state has two years to negotiate a deal. The UK departs at the end of March.As we reveal today, key parts of Scottish society have major reservations about the Brexit impasse and the prospect of no deal. Bodies such as the Scottish Trades Union Congress, the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations and the Scottish Chambers of Commerce support an extension of Article .Civic Scotland is backed up by political muscle. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, as well as Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Scottish Greens co-convener Patrick Harvie, are demanding that Brexit is delayed. Collectively these parties represent a clear majority of MSPs at Holyrood. The Prime Minister is under pressure to heed these calls.The argument for an extension is multi-faceted. The  referendum was won by Leave, but even the most passionate Brexiteer would have to concede there is nothing written in the stars about March . Supporters of the intervention believe it is more important to get a good deal than fixate on a specic date in the calendar.There are also political reasons for a delay. The Leave campaignrsquos specic promises have been pored over, scrutinised and mocked, but eurosceptics consistently said the UK would get some form of deal from the EU. Crashing out was never part of the offer ndash regardless of what we have heard in recent days and weeks. An extension would not contradict the verdict delivered in the referendum.But it is the potential economic damage that is fuelling calls for a push back. According to the Confederation of British Industry, no deal would cause GDP to shrink by up to % and put thousands of jobs at risk. Government analysis claimed the GDP hit could be .% over  years. A contraction of this sort would inevitably lead to huge reductions in public spending.Seeking an extension is within the gt of the House of Commons. Senior Labour figures seem broadly sympathetic and the Prime Minister has pointedly refused to rule out a delay.However, as with much of the Brexit melodrama, the key factor is the internal politics of the Tory party. The Prime Minister may recognise the move is inevitable, but she is worried about the cries of betrayal from right-wing colleagues who will see an extension as a plot to stay in the EU. The clock is ticking.

title: snp-to-select-candidates-for-european-elections-in-case-brexit-is-delayed
story: Nicola Sturgeonrsquos party will vet hopefuls in the next few weeks, while the Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrats are also exploring the idea in light of the current Brexit chaos.A senior SNP source said the move would send a ldquopowerful signal that scrapping Brexit is becoming a serious option.The UK is set to leave the EU on March th, with or without a deal on the terms of departure.The next elections to the European Parliament are scheduled for May, but the UK voters will not elect any MEPs as the country is scheduled to have left the EU.However, given that the UK Governmentrsquos draft withdrawal plan was comprehensively rejected by MPs last year, a range of options have moved into view.These include a no deal Brexit, which will occurMPs fail to raty an agreement struck with EU negotiators, and a second referendum.It is also possible for the UK to delay Brexit by requesting an extension to the Article  process which will lead to the UK leaving in March.And, as a result of a court case brought about by Scottish politicians, the UK can cancel Brexit by revoking Article .One of the lsquodelayrsquo models is extending the leave date by a few months, by which point the new round MEPs will have taken their seats.It would also be possible, but politically harder, to extend Article  for a substantially longer period.At a recent meeting of the SNPrsquos national executive committee , senior councillor Chris McEleny, who has contested his partyrsquos depute leadership election, is said to have raised the issue of the next European elections.It is understood he said the SNP, which favours a second referendum on leaving the EU, should select MEP candidates because it is possible Brexit may not go ahead.A source said: ldquoChris said thatArticle  is revoked or extended then Scotland will still require representation in the European Parliament, and so it would be diligent to have candidates in place.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos Depute Leader, confirmed the move to this newspaper:ldquoThe SNP is open to candidate applications for the  European Parliament election. We are working on the basis that the party will be vetting and selecting people to stand in the coming weeks.ldquoAs we are calling for the extension of Article  negotiation period between the UK and European Union - to avoid the clf edge of a no deal at the the end of March - it is vital we prepare for such a sht.ldquoI look forward to seeing who comes forward from the wealth of talent that exists in our mass membership ranks."A spokesperson for the Scottish Greens said: "With the deal dead and a Commons majority against No Deal, staying in has gone from a pipe dream to one of the most viable options. Preparing for a potential election is both the most responsible thing to do and a clear statement of intent. We intend to beat Brexit and and were increasingly confident that we can."A Scottish Liberal Democrat spokesperson said: ldquoWe are making the preparations necessary to enable us to ballot all our members to select our Euro candidatesthere is to be a European election.In a recent article, the Institute for Government think tank laid out four options for the UK continuing to have some form of representation in Brussels during an extension period.One of the stated options is to elect new MEPs until the end of the Article  period. ldquoThe UK would hold European Parliament elections this year, although not necessarily at the same time as the rest of the EU. This option would only make sensethere was an extended extension.

title: civic-scotland-brexit-must-be-delayed-and-chaotic-no-deal-avoided
story: Leaders in the business, trades union, charity and higher education sectors are behind calls to pause what promises to be the biggest economic change in the UK in over  years.Their call, which is echoed by the SNP, Scottish Liberal Democrats and the Greens, comes as the Prime Minister plans to unveil her Brexit "plan B" to MPs tomorrow.Under the terms of the  Lisbon Treaty, the UK is scheduled to leave the EU on March , two years after Theresa May invoked the so-called Article  which sets a time limit on negotiations.However, with Parliament rejecting the withdrawal plan presented by Theresa May, the prospect of the UK coming out of the -member bloc without a deal grows by the day.Various reports have warned that no deal would have negative economic consequences for the UK, with shortages of medicines and huge tailbacks at ports being predicted.Although March  is the official leaving date, an extension to the process can be granted by EU member statesthe UK makes a request.A range of high-profile bodies in Scotland has intervened by calling for Brexit to be delayed. Anna Fowlie, chief executive of the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations , which has around , members, said:ldquoAfter two years, we find ourselves on the brink of exiting the EU without a withdrawal agreement that both the UK Parliament and the EU can sign up to.ldquoThere is therefore no choice but to seek agreement with the EU to extend Article  to allow time for a second EU referendum to take place.Liz Cameron, director and chief executive of the Scottish Chamber of Commerce, said: ldquoThe rationale for a delay to the Article  timeline is growing each and every day in our business communities.ldquoAn extension to Article  would, first and foremost, avoid a no deal outcome on March , but it would also acknowledge that neither business nor government are prepared for such a scenario.Colin Borland, director of Devolved Nations at the Federation of Small Businesses , which has around , members, said: ldquoThis longer window could give Scottish business a much-needed opportunity to prepare while taking the fever out of the public debate.And David Watt, executive director of the Institute of Directors in Scotland, said business leaders are ldquovery concerned about a no-deal Brexit: ldquoWith all of this in mind, the inevitable conclusion is to extend Article . It may be the only option to ensure a deal and a reasonable transition period.Grahame Smith, general secretary of the Scottish Trades Union Congress, which represents around , trade unionists, also backs an extension, as does GMB Scotland Secretary Gary Smith.Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, principal of Glasgow University, is also strongly in favour of hitting the pause button as a way of delivering another referendum."With the Prime Ministerrsquos deal dead and Parliament in gridlock, there is only one way out ndash that is to request an extension to Article , and call a Peoplersquos Vote, he said.He added that an extension would ldquoappear the only opportunity to avoid the chaos of a No Deal outcome.In todayrsquos Herald on Sunday, the senior civic figures are joined by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Scottish Green co-convener Patrick Harvie.It also comes after three former Prime Ministers ndash John Major, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown ndash called on Article  to be either extended or revoked.Major, who was a Tory PM between  and , has said revoking Article  is the ldquoonly sensible course, as a no-deal Brexit would be ldquomorally reprehensible.Blair said he would be discussing the terms of an extension with the EUhe was still in Government, while Brown called for Brexit to be delayed by a year.Mayrsquos minority administration is opposed to an extension, but the Prime Minister has not ruled it out.However, the move would anger her pro-Brexit backbenchers and likely lead to further Cabinet resignations.Boris Johnson, the Brexiteer who quit as Mayrsquos Foreign Secretary in protest at one version of her deal, warned against an extension:"It would be so utterly pathetic that I do think it would not only cause widespread international dismay but also reinforce peoples view that there is some sort of plot at Westminster to stop this thing .":

title: prince-philip-given-words-of-advice-after-being-pictured-without-seatbelt
story: Images published on Saturday appear to show Prince Philip, wearing tinted glasses, back behind the wheel of a replacement Freelander on the Queenrsquos Sandringham estate in Norfolk.The -year-old passed a police eyesight test on Saturday morning as the investigation into Thursdayrsquos crash continues, with police saying ldquoany appropriate action will be takennecessary.Meanwhile the passenger in the Kia car involved has been named by the Sundayas Emma Fairweather, , who broke her wrist, and it said her friend suffered cuts to the knee in the crash.The newspaper reports Ms Fairweather, a mother-of-two, has told family and friends she is unhappy with how the incident has been dealt with by police and Buckingham Palace.The nine-month-old baby boy was unharmed, police said.A Norfolk Constabulary spokeswoman said the force was aware of the photographs taken on Saturday and that ldquosuitable words of advice have been given to the driver.She said: ldquoThis is in line with our standard response when being made aware of such images showing this type of offence.Buckingham Palace did not comment on the images.The duke reportedly said ldquoIrsquom such a fool as he was pulled from his wrecked Freelander on Thursday after it flipped on its side from the impact in the crash close to Sandringham.The Queenrsquos transport manager Alex Garty was seen at Sandringham as a replacement Freelander was delivered to the royal residence on Friday.Philip exchanged ldquowell-wishes with the injured women and appeared to have no lasting problems following the collision on the busy A-road, a palace spokeswoman said on Friday.A source said on the same day: ldquoThe dukersquos routine in the coming days will continue as normal.He was examined at hospital on doctorrsquos advice, but a check-up found no injuries of concern.Norfolk Police said the women in the Kia were treated at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Kingrsquos Lynn following the crash and later discharged.In a statement on Friday, the force said: ldquoAs is standard procedure with injury collisions, the incident will be investigated and any appropriate action taken.ldquoWe are aware of the public interest in this case, however, as with any other investigation it would be inappropriate to speculate on the causes of the collision until an investigation is carried out.Retired NHS worker Victoria Warne told The Sun she spoke to the duke at the scene of the crash as she looked after the injured occupants of the Kia.The -year-old, from Norfolk, said: ldquoThe passenger from the other car told me, lsquoI always wanted to meet a royal ndash but not this wayrsquo.She said the duke asked after the welfare of the Kia occupants, adding: ldquoHe looked so worried and told me, lsquoIrsquom such a foolrsquo.Her -year-old husband Roy helped the stricken duke out of his car, and he told The Sun Philip was overheard telling police he had been ldquodazzled by the sun.Nick Freeman, the lawyer dubbed Mr Loophole, said the duke could be prosecuted for driving without due care and attentionhe was deemed to have made a mistake.But he added: ldquoIf the sun was so low and right in your eyes, sometimes itrsquos impossible to see, and that may well have been the case, and that would afford him a defence.The duke, who retired from public duties in  but remains active, could also avoid prosecution by surrendering his licence, according to the lawyer known for representing celebrity clients like David Beckham.The crash happened as Philiprsquos Freelander pulled out of a side road on to a stretch of the A which was earmarked by the local authority for possible safety measures.The duke appeared to be travelling without a police protection officer, iniduals who guard all senior members of the Royal Family when at public and private events.At a meeting, coincidentally scheduled for Friday, Norfolk County Council approved plans to lower the speed limit from mph to mph, backed by speed cameras.

title: diane-abbott-condemns-unfair-treatment-on-question-time
story: Ms Abbott said that in the course of this weekrsquos programme, recorded in Derby, she was interrupted more than double the number of times Tory MP Rory Stewart was, and was not allowed to respond to a ldquoblatantly abusive remark from the audience.She said she had also been told Ms Bruce had made unpleasant remarks about her to the audience before filming began and the audience had been ldquowound up against her.In a statement, the BBC denied that any of lists on the programme had been treated unfairly.Writing for the Independent, Ms Abbott said: ldquoOver a long political career I have appeared on BBCQuestion Time innumerable times, but I have never had such a horrible experience asI had in Derby last week.In one exchange about letters sent between Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and Prime Minister Theresa May following the Brexit vote, Ms Bruce asked her: ldquoWhy donrsquot you just talk In another exchange with the journalist Isabel Oakeshott about whether Labour or the Conservatives were ahead in the polls, Ms Abbott said they were ldquokind of level pegging.Ms Bruce then interrupted to tell her: ldquoYou are behind, Diane.In her article, Ms Abbott said unlike the programmersquos previous host, veteran broadcaster David Dimbleby, Ms Bruce did not appear well-briefed and had got the polling wrong.ldquoSheappears to have got their figures from a Conservative Central Office handout. Above all, it seems she is not afraid to appear unfair as a presenter, she said.She said the BBC needs to start treating Mr Corbyn and his ministers as ldquolegitimate political actors and accord them the same respect they give to Tory ministers and MPs on the Labour right.ldquoIt would be wrong to blame Fiona Bruce for all this.Question Timehas had a new editor for some time, and seems more interested in entertainment than politics, she wrote.For those who havenrsquot seen it, we also said this yesterday #bbcqt pic OKMDYrLWkmdash BBC News Press TeamJanuary , ldquoIn the current abusive political climate, TV production teams need to reflect before they wind up live audiences against particular politicians. It may result in lsquogood televisionrsquo, but it can easily turn ugly.Ms Abbott said she is not asking for ldquospecial treatment, only fair treatment.She added: ldquoMany viewers and people in the audience for last weekrsquosQuestion Timethought that the way I was spoken about before the programme, the way that I was treated during the programme, and the chairing of the programme were decidedly unfair.In a tweet, the BBC news press team said that while a YouGov poll on the day of the programme put the Conservatives ahead, Ms Abbott was right to say other polls suggested Labour was either ahead or tied.ldquoWe should have made that clear, it said.A BBC spokesman said: ldquoWe are sorry to hear Diane Abbottrsquos concerns over Thursdayrsquos edition of Question Time and we have contacted her team today to reassure them that reports circulating on social media are inaccurate and misleading.ldquoDiane is a regular and important contributor to the programme.As we said earlier, we firmly reject claims that any of the was treated unfairly either before or during the recording.

title: thousands-urge-home-office-to-halt-removal-of-elderly-iranian-couple
story: Mozaffar Saberi, , and Rezvan Habibimarand, , bought a flat in Edinburgh in the late s and have four children,  grandchildren and a great-grandchild who are all British citizens.The couple spent time in the UK on visitor visas over the years but after visiting in November  they made an application to remain on human rights grounds which was refused by the Home Office.A second application was also refused and they are now appealing against the decision, with the case due to be heard on February .The couple are distressed at the prospect of being separated from their family who all live in Edinburgh.Their son Navid Saberi said: ldquoIt is very very stressful. They are elderly and not really keeping well and on top of their health problems it is a psychological effect, not knowing what is around the corner and what is going to happen in the future.ldquoThe prospect of leaving three generations of children, grandchildren and a great-grandchild and going back to Iran has not been easy for them.He added: ldquoThey have got nobody in Iran. It is just beyond belief.The couple also look after their severely autistic grandson who is non-verbal in order to help their daughter, an NHS nurse who is a single mother.Mr Saberi said his parents have a strong emotional bond with the boy and it could have a detrimental effect on himthey have to leave the country.John Vassiliou, partner at McGill  Co which is handling the case, said: ldquoMr Saberi is in his s, his we is in her s.If they go back to Iran itrsquos dficult for British citizens to visit Iran, they canrsquot just fly over asthey were going to Spain or France.ldquoThey are showing lots of signs of old age physically and mentally and they just want to be with their family. If they go back to Iran they will be alone.ldquoThey are very distressed by the whole process.ldquoIf they go back to Iran they will be two old people living alone whereas here they are living in Edinburgh with all their family around them.ldquoTheir family are all here and that social aspect and emotional support that they get here will disappearthey go back to Iran.More than , people have signed a petition on change.org calling on the Home Office to allow the couple to stay in the UK.Ian Murray, Labour MP for Edinburgh South, has voiced his support for the family.Itrsquos a very sad case. The main issue seems to be the change of Home Office rules in  by the now Prime Minister. Irsquom working with the family  their lawyers to try  persuade the Home Secretary to do the decent thing. Although the word ldquodecency seems to be banned in his dept. https:t.co KFswKtCOOmdash Ian MurrayJanuary , He tweeted: ldquoIrsquom working with the family  their lawyers to try  persuade the Home Secretary to do the decent thing.A Home Office spokesman said: ldquoAll UK visa applications are considered on their inidual merits, on the basis of the evidence available and in line with UK immigration rules.

title: diocese-in-apology-after-native-american-surrounded-by-jeering-youths
story: The Indigenous Peoples March on Friday coincided with the March for Le, which drew thousands of anti-abortion protesters, including a group from Covington Catholic High School in Park Hills, Kentucky.Videos circulating online show one youth staring at and standing extremely close to Nathan Phillips, an elderly Native American man singing and playing a drum.Other students, some wearing Covington clothing and many wearing red ldquoMake America Great Again hats and sweatshirts, surrounded them, laughing and jeering.This Veteran put his le on the line for our country. The studentsrsquo display of blatant hate, disrespect, and intolerance is a signal of how common decency has decayed under this administration. Heartbreaking. https:t.co NuPnYuFPmdash Congresswoman Deb HaalandJanuary , In a joint statement, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Covington and Covington Catholic High School apologised to Mr Phillips.Officials said they are investigating and will take ldquoappropriate action, up to and including expulsion.The statement said: ldquoWe extend our deepest apologies to Mr Phillips.ldquoThis behaviour is opposed to the churchrsquos teachings on the dignity and respect of the human person.According to the Indian Country Today website, Mr Phillips is an Omaha elder and Vietnam veteran who holds an annual ceremony honouring Native American veterans at Arlington National Cemetery.In a video posted online, he wiped away tears as he said of the incident: ldquoWhen I was there singing, I heard them saying lsquoBuild that wall, build that wallrsquo.ldquoThis is indigenous lands. Wersquore not supposed to have walls here. We never did.He said he wished the group of youngsters would instead put their energy into ldquomaking this country really great.State politician Ruth Buffalo, a member of the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara Nation, said she was saddened to see students showing disrespect to an elder who is also a US military veteran at what was supposed to be a celebration of all cultures.ldquoThe behaviour shown in that video is just a snapshot of what indigenous people have faced and are continuing to face, she said.She added that she hopes it will lead to some kind of meeting with the students to provide education on issues facing Native Americans.Congresswoman Deb Haaland, who had been at the rally earlier in the day, sharply criticised what she called a display of ldquoblatant hate, disrespect, and intolerance.She tweeted: ldquoThis Veteran put his le on the line for our country. Heartbreaking.

title: Iain Macwhirter  MPs must work together to unblock Brexit  or they   ll open the way for authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: iain-macwhirter-mps-must-work-together-to-unblock-brexit-or-theyll-open-the-way-for-authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: alyn-smith-eu-member-says-the-only-way-to-stop-this-madness-is-not-to-leave-eu-at-all
story: After the last few weeks of drama it is easy to be lose focus. Mrs Mayrsquos remarkable achievement of winning a party leadership vote then a vote of confidence while simultaneously heading the first UK Government in history to be found in contempt of Parliament and suffering the biggest-ever defeat is enough to make anyonersquos head spin.So plotting the next few weeks and months will be dficult, but there are a few gravitational forces that cannot be denied. Firstly, the clock is ticking. Unless something  actively happens, the UK and Scotland with it will leave the EU at pmon March . All this ldquotherersquos no majority in the Commons for No Deal is entirely meaningless, much like the iceberg did not actually bear the Titanic any ill will ndash exit will happen unless they actively do something to stop it.Secondly, Mayrsquos ldquodeal is only to exit. The future is dealt with only in an aspirational Political Declaration which is not worthless, but not binding either. So all the bumping of gums by MPs about Norway plus, Canada minus or upside-down Lichtenstein is all so much puff ndash these negotiations will only start after the exit. If we exit with a deal then a transition period kicks in where EU law will continue to apply as we try to negotiate the future relationship. Basically wersquoll have as little idea of the future, except wersquoll be outside the EU.SoBrexit happens, a ldquosoft Brexit where the UK remains in the single market and the customs union is undoubtedly the least damaging aspiration. This is why the Scottish Government and others have proposed it as a potential ldquoless bad option in the spirit of trying to find solutions, but they have also been clear EU membership is the best option.My concern is that there may well be a majority in the House of Commons for a Norway-style aspiration, but that it will be as unsustainable as all the other pipe dreams and in reality offers no stability at all. It would not withstand its first crisis, which would come all the harder because by then we would have lost the chance to avert it, having left the EU.So letrsquos take a look at it. EFTArsquos own website explains that ldquothe EEA EFTA states have little influence on the decision-making phase on the EU side. Instead, they focus on ldquodecision shaping. This involves informal consultations, attendance at some committees, and submission of views in generally short ldquocomments papers.This is not nothing, but it is light years from the power we have now in council and the European Parliament, and votes for ministers and the UKrsquos  MEPs.The term ldquoVassal State is overblown and grievously offensive to many EU states who actually were until recently, but the reality is that the amount of influence we would have is really very limited. From day one the deal would be ripe for destabilisation by unsatisfied Brexit ultras and their allies.The current members of the EEA and EFTA have spent many decades building up how it works they know the compromises and the shortcomings. The UK political class and administrative machinery are wholly unprepared for the reality that being a rule-taker would bring.You can imagine the mischief the Brexit ultras would make. In a world where outrage can be whipped up over rules on lightbulbs, kettles and toasters, theyrsquod be braying for vetoes to be used at the slightest hint of a controversial EU law. Of course, they would move on to attacking membership of the EEA on this basis.Some already see the EEA as a way to gradually move to a hard Brexit by stealth, so eventhe arrangement survived first contact it is unlikely it would be remotely stable in the medium to long-term.Itrsquos a measure of just how damaging Brexit is that the very best alternative is still much worse than EU membership.
